name: Ferruginous Duck
description: It has chestnut-brown feathers, a white belly, and a broad white wing stripe visible in flight. Males have a white iris.
spread_note: Breeds in southwestern Asia, central and eastern Europe, and northern Africa. Winters in southern parts of its breeding range, the Middle East, northeastern and western Africa, and southeastern Asia. Some southern populations are resident.
image_alt: Ferruginous Duck, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 33–36 cm; tail length 5–6.5 cm; wing length 17–20 cm; weight 0.5–0.7 kg
attractions: A diving duck, it can submerge quite deeply while foraging but prefers shallow coastal waters, rarely venturing onto open water. It often collects food from the surface or in shallow water. Besides seeds and other parts of aquatic plants, it feeds on aquatic invertebrates, amphibians, and small fish. Once, breeding ferruginous ducks could be observed in our waters, but today it’s a rarity to spot one. They typically stay in pairs or small groups, apart from other duck species, though larger flocks may be seen at wintering sites. The nest, made of plant material and lined with down, is placed in dense vegetation on the ground or in reeds over water.
breeding: Records show we’ve kept ferruginous ducks since at least 1988, though they may have appeared earlier.
